title: Hiking in Pembrokeshire
strapline: Epic cliff walks and hidden coves: discover Pembrokeshire's coastal trails.
metaTitle: Hiking Pembrokeshire | Coastal Trails & Walks | Adventure Wales
metaDescription: Explore the Pembrokeshire Coast Path! Discover stunning hiking trails, hidden beaches and dramatic cliffs. Plan your Pembrokeshire hiking adventure now.
heroAlt: Hikers on the Pembrokeshire Coast Path looking out over the sea towards St Davids Head.
introduction:
If you're serious about hiking, Pembrokeshire is calling. Forget gentle strolls – this is where the land meets the sea in a dramatic clash of cliffs, hidden coves, and wildflower meadows. The Pembrokeshire Coast Path, all 186 miles of it, is the star, but don't think you need to tackle the whole thing at once. The beauty of hiking Pembrokeshire lies in the diversity of its shorter sections. 

What makes it special? It's not just the scenery, it's the feeling of wildness. One minute you're dodging gorse bushes on a clifftop, the next you're descending into a secluded bay only accessible on foot. The birdlife is incredible – puffins on Skomer, choughs wheeling overhead, and the constant cry of gulls. And the history is palpable, from ancient Iron Age forts to the remnants of a once-thriving slate industry.

Hiking in Pembrokeshire isn't always a walk in the park. Expect some serious ascents and descents, exposed sections where the wind howls, and the occasional scramble over rocks. Mud is a given, especially after rain. But the rewards are immense: panoramic views that stretch for miles, the satisfaction of reaching a hidden cove, and the sheer exhilaration of being in such a raw and beautiful landscape.

Who's it best for? Seasoned hikers will relish the challenge of the longer routes, while those new to hiking can find shorter, easier sections to enjoy. Families with older children will also love it, but keep a close eye near the cliff edges. If you love dramatic scenery, wildlife, and a sense of adventure, then Pembrokeshire's trails are for you.

spots.name: St Davids Head Circular Walk
spots.description: A classic Pembrokeshire hike around the dramatic St Davids Head peninsula. Expect stunning coastal views, rugged cliffs, and the chance to spot seals. The route includes the Iron Age promontory fort of Carn Llidi.
spots.bestFor: Experienced walkers seeking dramatic coastal scenery and historical interest.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those with limited mobility or a fear of heights due to some cliffside sections.
spots.parking: National Trust car park at St Davids Head (Porthmelgan). Can get busy, especially in summer. £5 all day.
spots.insiderTip: The best time to walk St Davids Head is late afternoon, as the sun sets behind Ramsey Island, offering incredible light.

spots.name: Strumble Head Loop
spots.description: A relatively short but rewarding walk around Strumble Head, famous for its lighthouse and excellent wildlife viewing opportunities. Keep an eye out for seals, porpoises, and a variety of seabirds. The views of the coastline are panoramic.
spots.bestFor: Families, birdwatchers, and those looking for a shorter, accessible coastal walk.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those seeking a very challenging hike or dramatic elevation gain.
spots.bestSeason: All year round, but best in spring and summer for wildlife viewing.
spots.parking: Small car park at Strumble Head Lighthouse. Free.
spots.insiderTip: Bring binoculars! Strumble Head is one of the best places in Pembrokeshire to spot seals and porpoises from the shore.

spots.name: Marloes Peninsula Circular
spots.description: A varied walk around the Marloes Peninsula, featuring sandy beaches, dramatic cliffs, and stunning views of Skomer Island. Look out for the iconic Gateholm Island and the remnants of a wartime radar station.
spots.bestFor: Those looking for a mix of coastal scenery, wildlife, and historical interest.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those with mobility issues, as there are some steep sections and uneven terrain.
spots.parking: National Trust car park at Marloes Sands. Can get very busy in summer. £5 all day.
spots.insiderTip: Check the tide times before you go! At low tide, you can walk across to Gateholm Island (but be careful not to get cut off!).

spots.name: Stackpole Estate and Barafundle Bay Walk
spots.description: A gentler walk through the beautiful Stackpole Estate, featuring woodland, lakes, and the stunning Barafundle Bay. This walk is perfect for families and those looking for a less challenging coastal experience. Don't miss the lily ponds!
spots.bestFor: Families, casual walkers, and those looking for a less strenuous coastal walk.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those seeking a challenging hike or dramatic cliffside scenery.
spots.bestSeason: All year round, but best in spring and summer for wildflowers and sunshine.
spots.parking: National Trust car park at Stackpole Quay. Can get busy in summer. £5 all day.
spots.insiderTip: Pack a picnic and enjoy it on Barafundle Bay – regularly voted one of the best beaches in Britain.

spots.name: Green Bridge of Wales and Elegug Stacks Walk
spots.description: A spectacular coastal walk along the Castlemartin peninsula, featuring the iconic Green Bridge of Wales and the impressive Elegug Stacks. This area is part of a military firing range, so check access restrictions before you go!.
spots.bestFor: Experienced walkers who are comfortable with exposed coastal conditions.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those with young children or a fear of heights, due to some cliffside sections. Check firing range access before visiting.
spots.parking: Car park near the Green Bridge of Wales. Free.

startPoint.name: Green Bridge of Wales Car Park

spots.insiderTip: Check the MOD firing range schedule online before you go! Access to this area is often restricted due to live firing exercises. Avoid weekends to increase your chances of access.

spots.name: Dinas Island Circular Walk
spots.description: A beautiful circular walk around the Dinas Island peninsula, offering stunning views of Fishguard Bay and the surrounding coastline. This walk features a mix of woodland, cliffs, and beaches.
spots.bestFor: Those looking for a varied coastal walk with stunning views.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those with mobility issues, as there are some steep sections and uneven terrain.
spots.bestSeason: All year round, but best in spring and summer for wildflowers and sunshine.
spots.parking: Car park at Pwllgwaelod beach. Can get busy in summer. Pay and display.
spots.insiderTip: Stop for lunch at the Old Sailors pub in Pwllgwaelod after your walk – they have a lovely beer garden overlooking the beach.

spots.name: Newport to Cwm-yr-Eglwys Coastal Path
spots.description: A picturesque section of the Pembrokeshire Coast Path, linking the charming town of Newport with the unique village of Cwm-yr-Eglwys, famous for its partially submerged church. Expect stunning coastal scenery and sandy beaches.
spots.bestFor: Those looking for a scenic coastal walk with a cultural twist.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those with mobility issues, as there are some steep sections and uneven terrain.
spots.bestSeason: All year round, but best in spring and summer for wildflowers and sunshine.
spots.parking: Car park in Newport. Pay and display. Alternatively, park in Cwm-yr-Eglwys (limited spaces).
spots.insiderTip: Consider taking the Puffin Shuttle bus back to your starting point if you don't want to walk the route twice.

spots.name: Skomer Island Views from Martin's Haven
spots.description: A short but rewarding walk from Martin's Haven, offering stunning views of Skomer Island, famous for its puffin colony. This walk is relatively easy and suitable for families. You won't land on the island on this route, but views are spectacular.
spots.bestFor: Families, birdwatchers, and those looking for a shorter, accessible coastal walk with the chance to see Skomer Island.
spots.notSuitableFor: Those seeking a challenging hike or dramatic elevation gain. This route does not include a trip to Skomer itself.
spots.parking: Large car park at Martin's Haven. Pay and display.
spots.insiderTip: Arrive early, especially during peak puffin season, as the car park fills up quickly. The boat trips to Skomer also sell out in advance, so book online if you plan to visit the island.

practicalInfo.weather: Pembrokeshire's coastal weather can be unpredictable. Be prepared for sunshine, rain, and wind, sometimes all in the same day! Check the forecast before you go and be aware that conditions can change rapidly. Strong winds and heavy rain can make cliffside paths dangerous.
gearChecklist: Waterproof jacket and trousers – essential, even on sunny days.
Hiking boots – ankle support is recommended for uneven terrain.
Layers of clothing – easy to add or remove as the weather changes.
Sunscreen and hat – protect yourself from the sun, even on cloudy days.
Map and compass/GPS – navigation is crucial, especially on longer routes.
First-aid kit – be prepared for minor injuries.
Plenty of water and snacks – stay hydrated and energized.
Mobile phone – for emergencies, but don't rely on signal in all areas.
Rucksack - to carry all your essentials

gettingThere.publicTransport: Haverfordwest and Fishguard are the main train stations. The Puffin Shuttle bus service provides access to many coastal locations. National Express coaches also serve Haverfordwest.
gettingThere.parkingTips: Parking can be limited, especially during peak season. Arrive early, particularly at popular spots like St Davids Head and Marloes Sands. Consider using park and ride services where available.

practicalInfo.safety: Stick to marked paths and be aware of cliff edges. Check tide times before walking on beaches. Let someone know your planned route and estimated return time. In case of emergency, dial 999 and ask for the Coastguard. Be aware of livestock on the coast path.

faqs.question: How long does it take to walk the entire Pembrokeshire Coast Path?
faqs.answer: Most people take between 12 and 15 days to walk the entire 186-mile Pembrokeshire Coast Path. This allows for an average of 12-15 miles per day, with rest days factored in. Some ultra-runners have completed it in under 48 hours!

faqs.question: Is the Pembrokeshire Coast Path suitable for beginners?
faqs.answer: While the entire path is challenging, many shorter sections are suitable for beginners. The Stackpole Estate and Barafundle Bay walk is a good option for those new to hiking. Remember to wear appropriate footwear and be prepared for changes in weather.

faqs.question: Are dogs allowed on the Pembrokeshire Coast Path?
faqs.answer: Yes, dogs are allowed on most sections of the Pembrokeshire Coast Path, but they must be kept on a lead, especially near livestock. Some beaches have seasonal dog restrictions. Be responsible and clean up after your dog.

faqs.question: What is the best time of year to hike in Pembrokeshire?
faqs.answer: The best time to hike in Pembrokeshire is from May to September, when the weather is generally milder and drier. However, even during these months, be prepared for rain and wind. Spring and early summer are ideal for wildflowers and birdwatching.

faqs.question: Do I need to book accommodation in advance for hiking the Pembrokeshire Coast Path?
faqs.answer: Yes, it is highly recommended to book accommodation in advance, especially during peak season (June-August). Popular towns like St Davids, Tenby and Newport get booked up quickly. Consider booking several months in advance to secure your preferred choice.

faqs.question: Are there guided hiking tours available in Pembrokeshire?
faqs.answer: Yes, several companies offer guided hiking tours in Pembrokeshire. TYF Adventure and Preseli Venture are well-established operators that offer a range of guided walks and other outdoor activities. Guided tours can be a great option for those who want to learn more about the area and have a stress-free hiking experience.

faqs.question: How much does it cost to walk the Pembrokeshire Coast Path?
faqs.answer: The cost of walking the Pembrokeshire Coast Path varies depending on your accommodation choices, dining preferences, and whether you opt for guided tours. Budget around £50-£100 per day for accommodation, food, and transportation. Parking fees also need to be considered.

gearShops.name: Ma Simes
gearShops.address: High Street, St Davids, Pembrokeshire SA62 6SB
gearShops.description: A long-established outdoor shop in the heart of St Davids. They stock a wide range of hiking gear, clothing, and equipment, from waterproof jackets to hiking boots.

gearShops.name: TYF Shop
gearShops.address: 35 High Street, St Davids, Pembrokeshire SA62 6SA
gearShops.description: Part of the TYF Adventure company, they offer a curated selection of high-quality outdoor gear, clothing, and equipment. Known for their sustainable and ethically sourced products.

gearShops.name: Mountain Warehouse
gearShops.description: A national chain offering a wide range of outdoor gear and clothing at competitive prices. A good option for budget-conscious hikers.

postActivitySpots.name: The Shed
postActivitySpots.description: Famous for its fresh seafood, caught daily by local fishermen. Their fish and chips are legendary, and the atmosphere is relaxed and informal. Perfect after a day of hiking the coast path.

postActivitySpots.name: The Sloop Inn
postActivitySpots.description: A traditional pub in the picturesque harbour of Porthgain. They serve hearty pub fare and local ales. A great spot to warm up by the fire after a coastal walk.

postActivitySpots.name: The Sampler
postActivitySpots.address: 13 High Street, St Davids, Haverfordwest SA62 6SA
postActivitySpots.description: A deli and cafe serving delicious sandwiches, salads, and cakes. They also have a great selection of local cheeses and produce. Ideal for a quick and tasty lunch after exploring St Davids Head.

postActivitySpots.name: Cafe Mor
postActivitySpots.description: A unique street food vendor serving delicious seaweed-based dishes. Their lobster roll is a must-try. Located right on Freshwater West beach, it's the perfect spot for a post-surf or hike treat.

postActivitySpots.name: CWT
postActivitySpots.address: 12 High Street, St Davids, Pembrokeshire SA62 6SA
postActivitySpots.description: A delightful cafe offering delicious Welsh cakes, homemade soups and fresh coffee. A great spot to relax and refuel after a hike around St Davids.

accommodation.name: St Davids YHA
accommodation.description: A budget-friendly option close to St Davids Head, offering dorm rooms and private rooms. A great base for exploring the northern Pembrokeshire coast.

accommodation.name: Celtic Camping
accommodation.description: A clifftop campsite with stunning sea views, located near St Davids. Perfect for those who want to be close to nature and enjoy the Pembrokeshire coastline.

accommodation.name: Warpool Court Hotel
accommodation.description: A mid-range hotel with sea views, located between St Davids and St Justinians. A comfortable base for exploring the area.

accommodation.name: The Grove Narberth
accommodation.description: Luxury accommodation offering a spa and fine-dining. Perfect for a relaxing trip.

accommodation.name: Bryn Berwyn B&B
accommodation.description: A charming B&B near Newport, with stunning views of the Preseli Hills. A great option for those exploring the northern Pembrokeshire coast.

accommodation.name: Preseli Hills Glamping
accommodation.description: A luxury glamping site with stunning views of the Preseli Hills. Perfect for a relaxing and peaceful getaway.

events.name: Pembrokeshire Coast Path Challenge
events.description: A challenging trail running event along the Pembrokeshire Coast Path, with various distances available.

events.name: Saundersfoot New Year's Day Swim
events.description: Whilst this isn't specifically a hike, many use the new year's day swim as a way to get out into the outdoors after hiking on the beaches.

longTail: hiking pembrokeshire coast path national trail
